name: Zinc
summary: Zinc is an essential trace mineral required for immune function, wound healing, growth, reproduction, and neurological health. It plays a critical role as a cofactor for over 300 enzymes.
description: Zinc is a vital micronutrient involved in DNA synthesis, cellular repair, protein metabolism, and immune defense. It is naturally found in foods such as oysters, red meat, poultry, beans, nuts, and whole grains. Deficiency can lead to impaired immunity, delayed wound healing, growth retardation, hair loss, and depression. Supplementation is widely used for immune support, cold prevention, and skin health. Various formulations exist, including zinc gluconate, zinc sulfate, and zinc picolinate, with differing absorption profiles.

sections.text: Zinc functions as a cofactor for numerous enzymes involved in DNA/RNA synthesis, protein metabolism, and cell signaling. It stabilizes cell membranes, enhances immune function, and plays a role in synaptic plasticity and neurotransmission. Zinc also modulates inflammation and oxidative stress.

adult.deficiency treatment: 20–40 mg elemental zinc daily until corrected
adult.common cold: Lozenges providing 9–24 mg elemental zinc every 2–3 hours during waking hours, started within 24 hours of symptoms

sections.text: Immune and wound healing benefits may take days to weeks; cold symptom relief most effective when initiated within 24 hours.

serious: Copper deficiency with long-term high doses

other: Excessive zinc (>40 mg/day long term) can cause copper deficiency, anemia, and neurological symptoms.
Intranasal zinc (e.g., sprays, gels) has been associated with permanent loss of smell (anosmia) and is no longer recommended.

sections.pediatrics: Widely used in pediatric diarrhea management; safe at recommended doses
sections.geriatrics: Common deficiency in elderly; supplementation may support immune function

items: Oysters are the richest natural source of zinc.
Zinc lozenges are most effective against colds if taken within 24 hours of symptom onset.
Long-term supplementation should not exceed the tolerable upper intake level of 40 mg/day without medical supervision.
